title-group.article-title: Decreased non-emotional working memory capacity in women with PTSD: association with symptomatology

trans-title-group.trans-title: Disminución de la capacidad de memoria de trabajo no emocional en mujeres con TEPT: asociación con la sintomatología

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Background/objective: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is known to be associated with deficits in working memory (WM). However, findings regarding the relationship of PTSD with non-emotional WM have not necessarily been uniform. This study aimed to clarify the relationship between PTSD and non-emotional WM using the N-back task, a well-established WM task.

Method: A total of 111 women with PTSD and 120 healthy control women without trauma were enrolled. Most of the patients developed PTSD after experiencing interpersonal violence. Participants completed 0-back and 2-back tasks using non-emotional stimuli (number), as well as a standardised neuropsychological test battery and self-report questionnaires for PTSD and depression symptoms.

Results: The PTSD group showed significantly less accuracy in the 2-back task than the control group, while no significant difference was observed in the accuracy of the 0-back task. The PTSD group showed significantly prolonged reaction time compared to controls in both the 0-back and 2-back tasks. The prolonged reaction time in the 2-back task was significantly correlated with more severe overall symptoms and avoidance symptoms in the PTSD group after controlling for age.

Conclusion: Individuals with PTSD exhibited reduced WM capacity. Drawing on a relatively large civilian sample, this study contributes to the accumulating evidence of such deficits. Notably, the observed association between WM dysfunction and avoidance symptoms suggests a symptom-specific cognitive profile in PTSD.

list-item.p: This study examined working memory (WM) capacity in 111 women with PTSD and 120 non-trauma-exposed control women, using the N-back task without an emotional load. PTSD patients showed significantly lower WM, with reduced accuracy in the 2-back task (t = 4.2, p < .001) and prolonged reaction time in both 0-back (t = 2.1, p = .035) and 2-back (t = 3.2, p < .01) tasks, compared to controls.

Reaction time in the 2-back task was positively correlated with avoidance symptom severity (rho = 0.20, p = .036) and total PTSD severity (rho = 0.21, p = .028) after adjusting for age, suggesting an association between reduced non-emotional WM capacity and avoidance behaviour.

Our findings indicate that WM is impaired in PTSD even in the absence of an emotional load. The present study, which utilised a relatively large civilian sample, contributes to the accumulating evidence that individuals with PTSD exhibit deficits in non-emotional WM.

trans-abstract.p: Antecedentes/Objetivo: Se sabe que el trastorno de estrés postraumático (TEPT) está asociado a déficits en la memoria de trabajo (MT). Sin embargo, los hallazgos sobre la relación entre el TEPT y la MT no emocional no han sido necesariamente uniformes. Este estudio tuvo como objetivo clarificar dicha relación utilizando la tarea N-back, una tarea para evaluar la MT bien establecida.

Método: Se reclutó a un total de 111 mujeres con TEPT y 120 mujeres sanas sin antecedentes de trauma. La mayoría de las pacientes desarrollaron TEPT tras haber experimentado violencia interpersonal. Las participantes realizaron tareas 0-back y 2-back utilizando estímulos no emocionales (números), además de una batería estandarizada de pruebas neuropsicológicas y cuestionarios autoinformados sobre síntomas de TEPT y depresión.

Resultados: El grupo con TEPT mostró una precisión significativamente menor en la tarea 2-back en comparación con el grupo control, mientras que no se observó una diferencia significativa en la precisión de la tarea 0-back. El grupo con TEPT también presentó un tiempo de reacción significativamente más prolongado en comparación con los controles tanto en la tarea 0-back como en la 2-back. El tiempo de reacción prolongado en la tarea 2-back se correlacionó significativamente con una mayor gravedad de los síntomas en general y síntomas de evitación en el grupo con TEPT, después de controlar la variable edad.

Conclusión: Las personas con TEPT mostraron una capacidad reducida de memoria de trabajo. Basado en una muestra civil relativamente amplia, este estudio aporta evidencia adicional sobre estos déficits. Es especialmente notable la asociación observada entre la disfunción de la memoria de trabajo y los síntomas de evitación, lo que sugiere un perfil cognitivo específico para cada síntoma en el TEPT.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is defined by core symptoms of intrusion (or re-experiencing), avoidance, hyperarousal, and negative alterations in cognition and mood. These symptoms persist for more than one month, causing significant distress and impairment in social and daily functioning. In addition to these overt symptoms, PTSD has been reliably associated with impaired cognitive functioning in wide-ranging domains, including verbal learning/memory, information processing speed, attention, and WM (Scott et al., 2015).

Recent neurocognitive research suggests that the symptoms of PTSD may stem at least partly from maladaptive allocation of cognitive resources. Individuals with PTSD tend to anticipate and avoid reminders of traumatic events. Their future-oriented predictions are likely altered following traumatic experiences, leading to associations between these predictions and non-threatening stimuli. As a result, even stimuli unrelated to any actual threat may become linked to the perceived threat, triggering re-experiencing symptoms (Lissek & van Meurs, 2015). One neurocognitive model of PTSD proposes that top-down control within the central executive network (CEN), which includes the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC), becomes strengthened to suppress predictive threats (Leone et al., 2022). The CEN is thought to support higher-order executive functions such as cognitive control of thoughts, emotional regulation, and WM. According to this model, cognitive resources may be chronically allocated to the control of threat-related predictions, potentially straining WM capacity even in the absence of aversive stimuli (Leone et al., 2022; Nicholson et al., 2020).

Empirical research into WM in PTSD has employed various approaches, including emotional WM tasks that use facial recognition or trauma-related words (Mirabolfathi et al., 2022; Morey et al., 2009; Nejati et al., 2018; Schweizer & Dalgleish, 2011), and non-emotional memory tasks that use, for example, simple numbers, visuo-spatial information, and colour (Ainamani et al., 2017; Roncone et al., 2013; Russell & Mussap, 2023; Scott et al., 2015). Studies of emotional WM have shown reduced capacity in individuals with PTSD compared to controls (Mirabolfathi et al., 2022; Morey et al., 2009; Nejati et al., 2018; Schweizer & Dalgleish, 2011). In addition, N-back emotional WM training decreased the severity of PTSD symptoms (Larsen et al., 2019). Likewise, studies of non-emotional WM have reported impaired capacity in individuals with PTSD (Ainamani et al., 2017; Russell & Mussap, 2023; Scott et al., 2015). A recent systematic review by Norte et al. (2024), which examined non-emotional WM performance in PTSD populations, found that 10 out of 12 included studies in the review (83.33%) indicated a significant association between PTSD and WM impairment. However, only 1 out of 12 studies (8.33%) included more than 35 participants with PTSD, with the largest sample consisting of 99 individuals, and most studies were conducted in military populations. These limitations underscore the need for large-scale studies with civilian samples to evaluate the generalizability of non-emotional WM impairments in PTSD. On the other hand, the relationship between PTSD symptoms and non-emotional WM capacity remains inconclusive. While several studies have reported that PTSD symptom severity is negatively correlated with non-emotional WM capacity (Ainamani et al., 2017; Vasterling et al., 2002), others have suggested that this association may not be specific to PTSD. For instance, Blanchette and Caparos (2016) argued that WM deficits may be more attributable to trauma exposure itself rather than to a PTSD diagnosis. Bomyea et al. (2012) showed that WM performance was negatively correlated with the severity of intrusion but not with the severity of avoidance or hyperarousal subscales (Bomyea et al., 2012). This discrepancy may be due in part to the fact that these studies employed relatively small sample sizes (approximately 20–30 participants) (Landre et al., 2012; Vasterling et al., 2002), except those that were not limited to PTSD individuals (Ainamani et al., 2017; Bomyea et al., 2012). Such small sample sizes in previous studies may have obscured the results owing to the well-documented heterogeneity in symptomatic and biological features of PTSD. Neural dynamics in prefrontal regions vary across individuals with PTSD, depending on symptom profiles such as hyperarousal or emotional suppression (Aupperle et al., 2012). This neurocognitive heterogeneity underscores the need for a sufficiently large sample to examine symptom-specific associations with cognitive function. Against this background, we investigated the relationship between PTSD symptoms and WM using an N-back task with non-emotional stimuli (numbers). We employed a relatively large sample of >100 individuals, considering the heterogeneity of symptomatology in PTSD. Furthermore, the PTSD group in this study comprised a relatively homogeneous population in terms of ethnicity, sex, and trauma type, which would have minimised the potential effects of sample heterogeneity other than the distinct symptom profiles. We hypothesised that individuals with PTSD would show deficits in non-emotional WM and that the reduction in WM capacity would be correlated with the severity of PTSD symptoms.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Patients with PTSD were recruited from three institutes and their affiliated hospitals/clinics in Tokyo and Nagoya (two metropolitan areas in Japan). A total of 111 women with PTSD were enrolled in this study. The diagnosis of PTSD was initially evaluated by the attending clinicians, and subsequently confirmed using the Japanese version (Itoh et al., 2017) of the Post-traumatic Diagnostic Scale (PDS) (Foa, 1995) which is in high concordance with the DSM-IV. The presence or absence of Axis-I psychiatric disorders was assessed using a clinical interview by an experienced psychiatrist or clinical psychologist.

In addition, 120 non-trauma-exposed healthy controls were enrolled. They were recruited through advertisements in free local magazines, university campuses, and our website. They were interviewed by an experienced psychiatrist or clinical psychologist, and only those with no current or past history of Axis-I disorder (except for a past temporary depressive episode) were enrolled.

Inclusion criteria were: age of 18 years or older (both the patient and control groups), having an ability to give informed consent (both groups), and having PTSD as the primary diagnosis made by attending clinicians (only for the patient group). Exclusion criteria were: having serious physical illness that interferes with research participation (both groups), having schizophrenia, marked manic episodes of bipolar disorder, or intellectual disability (both groups), not being native Japanese speakers (both groups), not fulfilling the PTSD diagnosis confirmed by the PDS (only for the patient group), and fulfilling the criterion of traumatic event, i.e. ‘A criterion’, confirmed by the PDS (only for the control group).

This study was approved by the ethics committee of each institute involved, including National Center of Neurology and Psychiatry (Ethics Committee approval number: A2014-060, A2018-140, A2023-133), Tokyo Women’s Medical University (3339), and Nagoya City University (1123, 60-19-0142). Written informed consent was obtained from all participants.

sec.title: Impact of event scale-revised (IES-R)
sec.p: We used the validated Japanese version (Asukai et al., 2002) of the IES-R (Weiss & Marmar, 1997), a 22-item self-report questionnaire that assesses PTSD symptoms based on the criteria of the DSM-IV. This scale comprises three subscales, including ‘intrusion’ (e.g. intrusion of unwanted and upsetting memories, nightmares, flashbacks) with eight items, ‘avoidance’ (e.g. the tendency of avoiding thoughts or reminders about the traumatic experience) with eight items, and ‘hyperarousal’ (e.g. difficulty sleeping, getting easily startled, general irritability) with six items. Higher scores indicate more severe PTSD symptoms. Of the 111 patients, 2 did not complete this scale, and the data of IES-R were available for 109 patients.

sec.title: Beck depression inventory-second edition (BDI-II)
sec.p: We used the validated Japanese version (Kojima et al., 2002) of the BDI-II, a 21-item self-report inventory that assesses depression symptoms (Beck et al., 1996). The BDI-II was revised in 1996 from the original version (Beck et al., 1961) to be more consistent with DSM-IV criteria for depression. Higher scores indicate more severe depression symptoms.

sec.title: N-back task
sec.p: Our N-back task comprised two conditions: 0-back and 2-back, both of which included four blocks, each consisting of 24 trials. In the 0-back condition, participants responded ‘yes’ when a stimulus number (0-9) on the computer screen was identical to, and ‘no’ when it was different from, the target. A block of trials began with the presentation of the target number for 2000 ms. After the target, a fixation cross was presented for 500 ms, which was followed by 24 stimuli, each presented for 500 ms. The inter-stimulus interval was 1500 ms. In the 2-back condition, participants responded ‘yes’ when a stimulus number on the screen was identical to, and ‘no’ when it was different from, the one presented two beforehand. Similarly to the 0-back task, a fixation cross was presented for 500 ms which was followed by 24 stimulus numbers, each presented for 500 ms with a 1500 ms inter-stimulus interval. The percentage of ‘yes’ responses was controlled to be one-third of the 24 trials. All stimuli were presented in MS Gothic font in white on a dark gray background. The font size was 40 for the fixation cross and 55 for the numbers. The programme was developed using the Hot Soup Processor (ONION software) and presented on a 13-inch Mouse Computer notebook PC (LB-B511EN-BG).

sec.title: Repeatable battery for the assessment of neuropsychological status (RBANS)
sec.p: The validated Japanese version (Matsui et al., 2010) of the RBANS (Randolph et al., 1998), a standardised neuropsychological test battery, was used to assess participants’ general cognitive function. RBANS evaluates five cognitive domains derived from 12 subtests, including immediate memory (comprising list learning and story memory), visuospatial construction (figure copying and line orientation), language (picture naming and semantic fluency), attention (digit spanning and coding), and delayed memory (list recall, list recognition, story recall, and figure recall). Index scores of the five domains are combined to generate a total RBANS score, providing a global measure of neuropsychological performance. These age-corrected scaled scores are standardised, with a population mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. Scoring followed the manual guidelines (Matsui et al., 2010; Randolph, 1998). The RBANS was administered by a trained researcher.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: For the N-back task performance, the mean proportion of correct reactions (task accuracy) and the mean reaction time of correct reactions were calculated across the four blocks for the 0-back and 2-back conditions. To test whether the condition and group affected the performance, we fitted each dataset with a linear mixed-effect model (LMM), with condition (0-back vs. 2-back) and group (PTSD vs. control) as fixed effects, and with individual differences in intercepts as a random effect. When a significant main effect of group or condition was observed, a post-hoc pairwise analysis was further performed within each group or condition. To control for Type I error resulting from multiple comparisons, we applied Holm's correction to the p-values derived from these post-hoc tests. This analysis was performed using the lme4 library version 1.1.15 (Bates et al., 2015) and lmerTest library version 3.1-3 (Kuznetsova et al., 2017)—in R (Team, 2016).

To examine the association of PTSD symptom severity with WM, we used Spearman's rank correlation analysis between IES-R total and subscale (i.e. intrusion, avoidance, and hyperarousal) scores and N-back task performance (i.e. accuracy and reaction time). The reason why we used Spearman’s correlation was that the data of IES-R subscale scores, namely intrusion, avoidance, and hyperarousal, deviated from the normal distribution (all p < .05 by the Shapiro–Wilk test). The results of these correlations were first reported with a nominal p-value, and then with false discovery rate (FDR) correction using the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure (i.e. q-value) adjusted for the four indices of the N-back task. To control for potentially confounding variables, this correlation analysis was performed using unstandardised residuals corrected for the confounder(s), with the following two models: (1) adjusted for age only, and (2) adjusted for age and major depressive disorder (MDD) given that depression has been associated with WM (Nikolin et al., 2021). When a significant correlation was observed in the first model, this was further tested in the second model. Additionally, correlations between RBANS attention index scores and N-back task performance were also tested using Spearman’s correlation. These correlation analyses were performed using the Statistical Package for the Social Sciences version 28.0 (IBM Corp., Tokyo, Japan).
Statistical significance was set at two-tailed p < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Demographic, clinical, and psychological characteristics of patients with PTSD (n = 111) and healthy controls (n = 120) are summarised in Table 1. The patients and controls were matched for age. Most patients developed PTSD after experiencing interpersonal violence such as sexual and/or physical violence, and had been ill for more than six months at the time of study participation. A majority of them had psychiatric comorbidities such as MDD, and were receiving psychotropic medications such as antidepressants. They were on average moderately to severely ill, as indexed by the mean IES-R total score of 51.9, given that a score of 44 or more is used to indicate severe PTSD in many studies (reviewed in Andhavarapu et al., 2022). The attention index of the RBANS comprises digit span and coding subtests, both of which are widely used clinical measures of attention and WM capacity. This index, in addition to the other indices of the RBANS, showed a significant group difference, with the PTSD group performing worse than controls (t = 5.7, p < .001; see Table 1). In healthy controls, the attention index was not significantly correlated with accuracy on the 0-back or 2-back task or with reaction time on the 0-back task (all p > .1); while it was significantly, albeit weakly, positively correlated with reaction time on the 2-back task (rho = 0.19, p = .037). In patients with PTSD, the attention index was significantly positively correlated with accuracy on the 0-back task (rho = 0.39, p < .001) and 2-back task (rho = 0.42, p < .001); while it showed a significant, albeit weak, negative correlation with reaction time on the 0-back task (rho = –0.19, p = .045) and showed no correlation with reaction time on the 2-back task (p > .1).

sec.title: Comparison of N-back task performance between patients and controls
sec.p:
For the accuracy of the N-back task, significant main effects of group (F = 14.1, p < .001) and condition (F = 347.4, p < .001) were observed. Post-hoc analysis on group revealed no significant differences between patients and controls in the 0-back task (t = 1.6, p = .106), whereas patients showed a significantly less accurate performance than controls in the 2-back task (t = 4.2, p < .001). Post-hoc analysis on condition showed that the performance on the 2-back task was significantly lower than that on the 0-back task in the control (t = 12.1, p < .001) and PTSD (t = 14.2, p < .001) groups (Table 2 and Figure 1 left panel). Figure 1.
Plots depicting accuracy and reaction time in the 0-back and 2-back tasks. The left panel shows an accuracy rate in 0-back and 2-back tasks in healthy controls and patients with PTSD. The right panel shows reaction time in the 0-back and 2-back tasks in controls and patients. *p < .05; **p < .01; ***p < .001. Table 2.

Regarding the reaction time, significant main effects of group (F = 10.4, p < .01) and condition (t = 647.3, p < .001) were observed. Post-hoc analysis on group revealed that patients showed significantly longer reaction time than controls in the 0-back task (t = 2.1, p = .035) and the 2-back task (t = 3.2, p < .01). Post-hoc analysis on condition showed that reaction time was significantly longer in the 2-back task than in the 0-back task for both control (t = 17.9, p < .001) and PTSD (t = 18.1, p < .001) groups (Table 2 and Figure 1 right panel).

sec.title: Association of PTSD symptoms with N-back task performance
sec.p:
Table 3 presents the results of the correlation analysis on the association between PTSD symptoms and N-back task performance corrected for age. No significant correlations were observed of any symptom dimensions with accuracy on the 0-back task or 2-back task or with reaction time on the 0-back task. However, the IES-R total score (rho = 0.21, p = .028) and avoidance subscale (rho = 0.20, p = .036) were significantly positively correlated with reaction time on the 2-back task; although these significant correlations did not survive the FDR correction (both q > 0.05), and should therefore be interpreted with caution. These significant correlations of the IES-R total and avoidance scores with reaction time on the 2-back task, however, did not hold after controlling for comorbid MDD as well as age (both p > .05). sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of this study provide two lines of evidence regarding the relationship between PTSD and non-emotional WM. First, compared to controls, patients showed significantly lower accuracy in the 2-back task (but not in the 0-back task) and significantly longer reaction time in both the 0-back and 2-back tasks. Importantly, our N-back task assesses WM by requiring simple numeric retention and manipulation, minimising reliance on higher-order cognitive functions such as language comprehension or complex calculations. Therefore, the observed deficits in the 2-back task are likely due to WM-specific impairments rather than general cognitive dysfunction. Furthermore, the significant group difference in the RBANS attention index, which is considered a standard clinical measure of WM capacity, showed a similar pattern to the N-back performance. This convergence between experimental task performance and standardised clinical assessments reinforces the interpretation that PTSD is associated with reduced WM, even in the absence of emotional load. On the other hand, patients and controls showed different patterns of association between attention index and N-back performance. More specifically, the attention index was significantly positively correlated with accuracy on the N-back task in patients but not in controls, which suggests that the WM/attention deficits in the PTSD group may result in similarly worse performance in both tests, thereby generating the significant correlation. Second, we found a significant correlation between PTSD symptoms and WM capacity, such that individuals with more severe avoidance symptoms showed prolonged response time on the 2-back task. After controlling for the effects of comorbid depression, however, this association disappeared, suggesting that the link between avoidance and prolonged response time may be partly driven by depression comorbid with PTSD. Although the significant correlation between avoidance symptoms and 2-back response time did not hold after the FDR correction, the observed pattern is consistent with theoretical accounts suggesting that individuals who have difficulty inhibiting responses, particularly under high WM demands such as in the 2-back task, may develop avoidance strategies (Aupperle et al., 2012).

In the N-back task where participants are requested to determine whether the currently presented stimulus matches a specific target condition, it is commonly recognised that there is often a trade-off between accuracy and reaction time (Ratcliff et al., 2016). Specifically, prioritising accuracy tends to result in longer reaction time and vice versa. Among individuals with PTSD, consistent prolongation of reaction time was observed in the N-back task compared to healthy controls. These findings suggest that individuals with PTSD may experience delayed access to memory, even when the memory task is unrelated to emotionally salient stimuli, or they may adopt a strategy that prioritises accuracy at the expense of response speed – or perhaps both factors contribute.

Previous research on the relationship between non-emotional WM and PTSD symptoms has produced somewhat mixed findings. For example, Blanchette and Caparos (2016) found that trauma-exposed individuals show reduced WM performance compared to non-exposed controls. Notably, however, PTSD symptoms did not mediate this relationship in their study, suggesting that WM impairments may be more strongly linked to trauma exposure itself rather than PTSD diagnosis. However, another study reported a negative correlation between intrusion and WM capacity (Bomyea et al., 2012). These findings contrast with the present study, in which reduced WM capacity was specifically associated with avoidance, but not intrusion symptoms. Two potential factors may explain this discrepancy. First, differences in the tasks used may account for the differential findings. Bomyea et al. (2012) employed the Operation Span Task (Ospan), which involves both simple memory retention and mathematical processing. This task likely engages cognitive processes distinct from those required by the N-back task used in the current study, as calculation ability largely depends on long-term memory and the rules of numerical operations (Butterworth & Walsh, 2011). Task-specific demands differentially recruit neural systems that are variably associated with distinct PTSD symptom clusters. The Operation Span Task (Ospan) used in Bomyea et al. (2012) primarily involves maintaining information in WM while inhibiting interference from concurrent mathematical processing, suggesting that inhibitory control, likely mediated by regions such as the inferior frontal gyrus, plays a central role in performance. In contrast, the 2-back task used in the present study requires continuous updating of information while suppressing responses to previously presented stimuli. According to Aupperle et al. (2012), individuals with PTSD may have difficulty inhibiting responses to trauma-related cues, leading to greater reliance on avoidance as a coping strategy. Our observed association between avoidance symptoms and prolonged 2-back reaction time may reflect such inhibitory control difficulties under high cognitive demand. Second, differences in participant characteristics may be involved. Both Blanchette and Caparos (2016) and Bomyea et al. (2012) examined participants with a history of trauma exposure, whereas the current study targeted clinical patients. It is possible that individuals with PTSD and trauma-exposed individuals without a PTSD diagnosis differ in WM performance. This suggests that future research should target trauma-exposed non-diagnosed individuals as well as clinical PTSD populations. Such efforts will provide a more comprehensive understanding of the cognitive mechanisms underlying PTSD.

In the present study, a significant correlation was observed between avoidance symptoms and reduced WM capacity. The potential neural basis of this association can be informed by existing neurocognitive models. Leone et al. (2022) reported that stronger functional coupling between the dlPFC and the hippocampus was associated with greater severity of avoidance symptoms. Aupperle et al. (2012) suggested that WM impairments in PTSD may be better explained by dysfunction across a broader frontoparietal-limbic network, including the PFC, anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), and insula, rather than by unidirectional control exerted by a single region. Moreover, a review by Quinones et al. (2020) highlighted the critical role of inflammatory activity in the PFC and ACC in modulating amygdala function, which plays a key role in fear regulation. Accordingly, the observed association between avoidance symptoms and prolonged reaction times in the 2-back task may reflect inefficiencies in cognitive resource allocation across this distributed network. This view is further supported by a randomised controlled trial conducted by Westphal et al. (2021), which investigated the effects of tolcapone, a catechol-O-methyltransferase inhibitor that modulates dopamine levels. Administration of tolcapone led to increased activation in bilateral frontoparietal regions and improved WM performance, particularly among individuals with more severe PTSD symptoms. These findings suggest that reduced WM capacity in PTSD may be linked to alterations in neurotransmitter function within frontoparietal networks. Taken together, the association between avoidance symptoms and WM performance in PTSD should be understood within a multilayered, integrative framework involving frontoparietal-limbic circuits and neurotransmitter systems, particularly those related to dopaminergic signalling. Future studies should employ comprehensive analyses of brain network dynamics and physiological markers to further elucidate these multidimensional mechanisms.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This study had several limitations. First, the cross-sectional nature limits the ability to make inferences regarding the causality between WM impairment and the development of PTSD (symptoms). Second, as our participants consisted only of women, our findings cannot be readily extrapolated to male individuals with PTSD. Finally, without the group of trauma-exposed non-PTSD individuals, we cannot differentiate the effect of PTSD on WM from the potential effect of traumatic experiences per se.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The present study, using a relatively homogeneous sample in terms of ethnicity (i.e. Japanese), sex (i.e. women), and type of traumatic exposure (i.e. primarily interpersonal violence), shows that WM is impaired in PTSD, especially in relation to avoidance symptoms. By employing a non-emotional WM task in a relatively large civilian cohort, this study strengthens the evidence that cognitive dysfunction in PTSD extends beyond emotional processing. These findings contribute to bridging behavioural evidence with neurocognitive models of PTSD and underscore the importance of linking symptom dimensions with their underlying cognitive and neural mechanisms.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We would like to thank all participants who took part in this study.

sec.title: Author contributors
sec.p: NU, ML, MI, HH, and YK designed the study. ML and MI devised the present N-back task. MM supervised the conduct of RBANS. HH, KI, TK, and YK provided resources. ML, MI, HH, M Niwa, KI, M Narita, WN, RI, and YK collected the data. NU and HH undertook the statistical analyses and wrote the draft of the manuscript. HH and ZN supervised the statistical analysis and helped in drafting the manuscript. YK supervised the entire project. All authors contributed to and have approved the final manuscript.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: Data described in the manuscript will be made available upon reasonable request to the corresponding authors (HH and NU).

sec.title: Disclosure statement
sec.p: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).
